M-maybe it’s a guide to getting out of here! [PAPER RUSTLING] And… [STAMMERING] Oh… it’s, um… it’s just some sort of… speaker box thingy…

[BRIEF PAUSE OF HESITATION]

[TAPE RECORDER BUTTON PRESS]

[SOUNDS OF TAPE RECORDER PLAYING, CONTINUING IN THE BACKGROUND UNTIL RECORDING ENDS]

TREXEL, FROM THE TAPE RECORDING 
Woah now! What’s this doing? Why is the lighting so moody in here? Stop that! Stop that! You can’t fool me, you swirling-eyed demon! Take that! [SOUND OF A HIT FROM A BLUNT, WOODEN OBJECT ON THE TAPE RECORDER] And that! [HIT] And how about one of these?! [HIT, A SLIGHT SCRAPING AS THE OBJECT IS DROPPED].

[TREXEL BREATHING HEAVILY FROM EXERTION] You’re a tough old thing, aren’t you? Wh-what’s this now? A note. “Make your statement.” [PAPER RUSTLING] Okay: I was never there, Your Honor! At the time of the offense I was committing another, more serious, far elsewhere on the station, so it could not possibly have been me! And anyway, you can’t prove a thing! And I should know because I broke into the prosecutor’s quarters and read their notes! I’m not corrupt! You’re corrupt! The defense rests! No further questions! Case: dismissed!

…Oh wait there-there’s more: [PAPER RUSTLING] “Make your statement; face your fear.” Fear. Fear… [PAPER RUSTLING] Well, I-I don’t have any fears! Nope! Not… not me! I’ve-I’ve never had a fear! Wh-what’s fear? That’s what I say! Old no-fear Geistman, that’s what, uh… [NERVOUS SWALLOWING] that’s what they call me.

[BRIEF PAUSE OF HESITATION]

Uh… Well there was one night… Uh, this was years ago, you understand, I was a young consultant, skin raw from the academic fluid of the private education tanks and just… so full of hopes and dreams for the future. I had it all back then: a freshly minted sales license, a membership to all the executive clubs, and a liver you could bounce micro-asteroids off.

I was, well… I suppose you would say naive. Young and naive. Young, naive, and stupid, and drunk. I’d been celebrating my graduation–don’t judge me! Oh, and sleep-deprived–look, the point is that even then I-I wasn’t conforming to the web of rules and regulations and basic safety measures that society wanted to chain me down with.

But, despite all of that, I knew that sales is where I wanted to be. The rush of the pitch! The thrill of the deal! The glee of the double invoice! The ritual hunt of the client! And the retainers. Oh my Board, the retainers. But, as my mother always said, “Who are you and why are you in my office, you short idiot?!” Wait, sorry, not that one. She always said, “Nothing in this universe comes without a price, you short idiot.” And no matter how much taller I got that… never changed.

So, after I arrived at my new office that evening, it was late, far later than work hours, but I just wanted to see where it was all going to happen! Where my germination would to begin!

[SPOOKY BACKGROUND MUSIC, THE SAME FROM THE MAGNUS ARCHIVES]

The halls were dark. Just the dim lights of the instructional propaganda notice board glowing with the words “Don’t even think about it, buddy!” There was the door. In bold letters, “T. Geistman: Sales Consultant.” A tear crept to the eye. All mine! Finally, it’s all mine! I pressed my tongue to the fluid identification panel: the taste of success! I pressed my flesh onto the print reader: the touch of victory! And I whispered into the sonic identificator, [WHISPERS: “Geistman,”] the sound of justice!

The door glid open–Glid, is that right? Glidd-ed? Gload-ed? Gled–the door opened and I stepped in and it was dark, far darker than the vast, inky void outside showing through the viewport on the opposite wall. That had stars picked out across its surface, like a sparse carpet of diamonds spilled by a careless debutant or a… clumsy jeweler.

And there… there on the desk, something… terrible. Something unimaginable. I tried to look at it closely but my mind spiraled and refused to focus. My understanding slid over this… thing like a slimy clone across a steel floor. What was this, this hideous thing, warping the space around it with malevolent force? Was I mad? Had my sanity been ripped away from me that instant and cast out into that void? Had the end come? A promising life cut short without care?! Without reason?!? No! No… because I’m exaggerating.

But on that desk was… [PAUSE] it was… [LABORED BREATHING] a-a timetable! [THROAT CATCHING AT THE MERE THOUGHT FOLLOWED BY LABORED BREATHING] Oh, jailer of time! Oh, cruel foreman of the clock! Segmentor of moments in the ever-changing now. Was this the end of my hopes, my dreams, trapped in a desolate future of turning up to things at the time I had previously stated that I would arrive!?

My vision was swimming; my chest, tight. I couldn’t breathe! I felt like I was being buried alive under a mountain of mild responsibility! I couldn’t stay there. The hunger for freedom overwhelmed me and my legs worked automatically. I ran for… Board, I don’t know how long I ran for, or how far, but I ran and ran until my strength gave out. My ears ringing, a pounding in my chest, every part of me aching and burning. I looked about for anyone: friend, stranger, someone I could talk to, maybe persuade to buy me a drink. But there was no one! In that moment I felt so… lonely. Just me and my thoughts. It was like the education tanks all over again, except I wasn’t upside-down being flushed from Blame Shift-o-nomics to Introductory Arithmetricks.

I look back on that day now and think that maybe that was the first time things… maybe things weren’t going to be smooth sailing for Old Trexel Geistman. Old Geisterino. The Geistenator! [SIGH] Things weren’t going to be as easy as I thought…

[BRIEF PAUSE]

Well, story ends, or statement, or whatever. What happens now? Oh! A trophy! Or a nice side table for my living quarters. Something in dark wood. Board, I could slaughter a flaxen-whisk right no–

DAVID

GERTRUDE
Right. If you’re listening to this, then it is likely that- (she breaks off, sighs) No. Let’s not beat around the bush. If you’re listening to this, it means I’m dead. And you have been chosen to be my replacement as Head Archivist.

Hopefully, this means you, Sasha, but if someone else is hearing this, and Elias has made a different choice for some reason, then these words are still very much intended for you.

Before I continue: It is very important to be absolutely clear this is not a joke. Nor is it any sort of prank, or game. Your colleagues have not convinced me to record this as an attempt to… haze you. This is completely serious. And very, very important for you to know.

If it is you I’m talking to, Sasha, hopefully your background in Artifact Storage will lend a certain degree of.. credence to my words. But others may have to take it on trust.

All I can do is assure you I am deadly serious. (sigh) So. The first thing you have to do is accept that you are in great danger, and will be for the rest of your life. There are now things that will actively be trying to kill you, due to your new role as Archivist, and Elias has plans for you that are little better.

You will also be unable to relinquish the position or quit the Institute, finding you are supernaturally compelled to remain.

In fact, it occurs to me that attempting to do so is probably the quickest and easiest way to establish the truth of what I am telling you, so I suggest you do so at the earliest possible opportunity.

Things you need to be aware of:

There exists in our world supernatural entities of incredible power that reflect and feed on the fears of all living creatures, but most commonly humans. Many consider them gods, and while I believe that is far too simplistic a comparison, for our purposes here it is perhaps the most useful shorthand.

They do not rule our world, but they do exercise considerable power, which they generally manifest in the form of monstrous beings that spread further fear- or, incarnations, those humans who have willingly, though not always knowingly, chosen to take on the power of these entities.

You, unfortunately, have unwittingly made the decision to become one of those incarnations. For the Institute serves a being variously known as: The Eye, It Knows You, The Beholding, The Ceaseless Watcher. It is the fear of being watched, and judged, and having all your secrets known. The Institute serves as a way for it to harvest the fears of the other entities, dragging out the suffering of those who come to give statements and- claiming their terror.

But, there is another part of being the Archivist. These.. beings, these.. gods of fear- their followers believe that they have… rituals. Grand projects which, if successful, would allow them to enter our world, reshaping it in- unthinkable ways. Molding it into a dimension where terror is as natural as gravity.

You are now one such ritual.

I do not know the exact details of it, but be wary of whatever Elias asks you to do.

Oh, yes. On the subject of Elias: Trust nothing he says. He was originally known as Jonah Magnus, the founder of this Institute, and I have known him also as James Wright, the previous head of this Institute.

He has certain.. abilities of clairvoyance, which allow him to perceive out of any eye, real or symbolic, so be wary. Play ignorant as long as you can while you expand your own research.

I’ve managed to keep the Archives in a state of chaos for decades, as I believe his plan would benefit from their organization. But I leave that to your judgement. Certainly, the longer he is ignorant of how much you know, the better.

Above all else: be ready. There are many things out there loyal to other powers which know your importance to the Eye, and will want. You. Dead.

You are entering a new world, a place I’ve lived for most of my life. A place… (she sighs) A place that will often demand a high price from you. Pay it without hesitation, because one way or another, the world is now on your shoulders. (sigh)

I wish I had more time to explain it to you. But time is short, and hopefully my actions tonight will ensure that this tape never needs to see the light of day.

But if you are hearing it, then- good luck. Do what you have to do.

[SHE SIGHS, HEAVILY.]

[HE SIGHS HEAVILY. ALL AT ONCE, THE STATIC FROM EARLIER COMES RUSHING RIGHT BACK IN AS IF IT HAD NEVER LEFT.]
ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT)
There is a wound in the earth.

A bayonet gouge scored through the soft and sodden mud for uncounted miles. A trench that marks the front line of a war that has no name. It has always been raging, deep in the hearts of the powerful and those that thirst to see bodies piled high in their name.

And now it has a battleground. A thousand pointless conflicts and bitter stalemates stitched together like a triaged chest wound.

It is a butchered border, a thin and punctured membrane between the unending meat grinder and the terrified victims it longs for.

You may find this trench reaching all across the world, and it will never stop, never be satisfied, never think of peace.

Charlie stands there, waiting in a transport.

Once, it was a thin metal landing craft, drifting slowly through a fetid lake. The waters were red and black by turns with blood and oil and the floating bodies of those before them, that were pushed aside by the boat’s wake.

Next to him, Charlie saw Ryan, who he’d known since childhood, though the other details were hazy. Ryan gave him a thumbs up and an encouraging smile- before his face exploded inwards to a sniper’s bullet, peppering the boat with shards of bone and gore.

Charlie swallowed, and waited as the bullets kept coming and those around him died but did not fall, propped up as they were by the pressing mass of people around them.

He could not move, and as he waited for the shot that would take him, his legs fell away in fear.

Now he is in a helicopter, strapped in tight and unable to move. The man in the gunner’s chair is dead, bound limp in his seat harness, half his jaw gone. The thump-thump-thump of the rotors pulses through Charlie like a toothache, and he cannot hear the shouts and cries of his comrades.

He looks out of the side as a telltale line of smoke arcs up and around towards them from the scorched earth far below. He cannot hear his own scream.

He lies upon the ground, amid the twisted wreckage of whatever he was trapped in, feeling the jagged shards of broken bone dig into him.

Charlie looks up, and sees something floating there, silently. It is sleek, and merciless, its featureless carbon-fiber face regarding the shattered man dispassionately. The drone’s camera blinks once, twice as he tries desperately to crawl away, pain lancing through every part of him.

The thing makes no sound as it follows him, matching the excruciating pace of the bleeding soldier. Charlie knows when it decides to fire, he won’t even hear it.

He places his hand down and it sinks, suddenly, into the mud. He cries out as the rusted barbed wire curls itself eagerly around his wrist, digging into his skin.

Tasting fear, more wire slithers through the churned earth towards him, stretching and gripping him tight, rough needles puncturing his legs and chest and throat, pulling him down and holding him steady as the drone lingers, its blankness giving no hint of the thoughts behind its trigger.

There is a rumbling in the earth around him as a tank speeds along its unstoppable path, and Charlie is immediately pulled under its tread.

He has a moment of shocked horror before being reduced to a smear in the mud.

Inside the tank, Ishaan screams.

Ishaan remembers the recruiters. He was promised valor, and camaraderie, and the chance to be part of something meaningful. He knew that part had been a lie, but then- so was the choice. His alternative was stagnant poverty, and that was really no choice at all.

The money would help his family, and he could spend some years in hell, if he needed to. For them.

But he didn’t know about this war, that had always been raging and would never stop. How could he have known what the trench would be?

They had taken him, dragged him from the flooded foxhole where he had sheltered for a moment’s brief respite, and taken him to the tanks, those monstrous beasts of iron that rolled forever forward, guns firing and treads leaving the earth scarred in their wake.

They pass above the trench again and again and they never turn around, pushing onward, ever onwards, the bones that stick in their gears not slowing them for a moment.

Ishaan had been afraid. Terrified that they were going to strap him to it, pin him to the Goliath’s hull like all the other flayed flags of war, striking fear into the hearts of the enemy.

But instead they fed him to it, tossed him into its burning innards and sealed the hatch behind him.

Now, his body has contorted itself to fit, his fingers clutched around the firing lever; pulling it frantically is the only thing that will reduce the impossible heat even for a moment.

From the tiny slit in the metal, he can see other soldiers: baby-faced friends and the monstrous, pig-faced enemy, both falling underneath his iron coffin’s advance.

He tries to cry, but his tears turn to steam.

He waits, craving and dreading the final kiss of the bombs, the terrible thundering guns so far away that none have ever seen them, raining their arbitrary ruin upon the endless fields of the dead and dying.

They are perhaps the only things that can fell the tanks, splitting them like rotten fruit beneath the force of their rounds.

Ishaan begs, pleading with whatever god of hatred and pain he hears piping gently on the breeze to let the bombs rain down on him. To release him from his imprisonment in a single flash of destruction.

But when his prayer is answered, the white-hot agony of melted and crumpled metal is like nothing he could dream of.

When Hasana takes him into triage, she can barely bring herself to look at him.

She wheels his stretcher to its place in the stinking, vaulted tent that serves as a field-hospital, walking through a sea of bandages and around the piles of festering gauze.

She leaves the shuddering man and approaches a nearby doctor, its long form crouched over the open chest of a patient, its many hands a frenzy of scalpel, bonesaw, and needle as it giggles beneath its surgeon’s mask.

She wants to ask about the wounded, about what to do, where to put the new ones, how to help them, but even if her voice was not drowned out by the thousand-strong chorus of moaned and pained yelling that fills the tent, the doctor doesn’t seem to notice her.

Hasana’s eyes fall on the entrance to the tent, and she sees the line of civilians, stretching away into the distance. They are no less maimed, their agonies no more bearable, but there is simply no room.

She tries to apologize, but instead she closes the tent.

As she does so, she sees the trench behind her, and, not for the first time, Hasana considers trying to run.

But there is no mercy for deserters here. On one side of the trench the hungry guns of the vile enemy wait. And on the other, the just guns of heroes will cut you down no slower, save perhaps a breath to call you coward.

So she waits there, in the middle, with the weeping, wounded, and the soon to be dead. Waiting for the enemy to overrun them.

Sometimes, in the distance, Hasana sees them. The enemy, their skin rough, dark, and scaly; their faces twisted around cruel tusks, viciously sharpened teeth, and a pair of beady red eyes. Their lips are smeared crimson with the blood of children, and their greatest delight is to pluck the eyes of the innocent with their bayonets.

To call them monsters is the simple truth. They feel no pain, no remorse, and seek nothing but carnage.

Sometimes, in the distance, Hasana can even see an enemy triage tent, almost identical in appearance to her own. She can only imagine the atrocities that must take place inside.

Far in the distance, she sees Alexei look out over the battlefield, and her stomach turns at the detestable wrongness of his face.

Alexei in turn looks out from deep in the trench. He catches sight of the enemy, their shriveled rat-like heads causing the bile to rise in his throats.

He is bored. The boredom is the worst part, the part that erodes his will and drops him to despair.

There is nothing to do, nowhere to be. The only thing to occupy his mind is the inevitability of the next attack, the next order to charge, the next dropping bomb.

There is no way to know when and where these things will come. But no one will talk of anything else.

His stomach growls, the hunger pushing its sharp fingers out from his belly. There are no more rations, and what there is tastes of cordite and sand, and coats his tongue in an oily film that makes him gag.

He has heard the enemy will eat your body if they find it in the mud. They won’t even check if you’re dead first. Alexei shudders at the thought.

From far down the trench, a cry of panic cuts through the silence. A faint haze can be seen in the distance, moving with the breeze. A new weapon?

Alexei feels his knees start to buckle as he sees his comrades stagger out of the cloud. Their melting teeth flow down their faces like tears, and their limbs begin to fold and collapse as the bones within them liquefy.

He turns and starts to flee down the trench. There is no cruelty so foul the enemy will not perpetrate it.

He runs almost headfirst into a portly man in a tailored suit with a blood-red flower on his lapel. He smiles, pale skin splitting beneath his bristling white mustache, and he begins to shake Alexei by the hand.

“Good lad,” he says. “Good lad. Heroes one and all. A noble sacrifice.”

Alexei starts to speak, to say he doesn’t want to be a hero; he doesn’t want to be a sacrifice; he wants to go home. But the man with the flower reaches his hand into the soldier’s chest, and with a single, jolly motion, plucks out Alexei’s heart and places it in his wallet.

Next to his bleeding corpse, Charlie wakes from what passes for sleep in this place. A sergeant is yelling at him, screaming for him to take his gun and get into the waiting transport. There’s about to be another attack, and heavy losses are expected.

A familiar fear courses through him, but Charlie still picks up his gun, and goes back to the war.

[EXT. MID-NORTHERN UK, SOMEWHERE]
[TAPE CLICKS ON.]
[THERE’S A BARKING SORT OF SOUND ON REPEAT. THE BUZZING OF A FLY DRONES AT THAT VOLUME THAT’S JUST LOUD ENOUGH TO BE AN ANNOYANCE. OTHER BUGS, TOO. SOME UNINTELLIGIBLE CHATTERING IN THE BACKGROUND, HIGH IN PITCH.]
[THIS IS TERRITORY OF THE CORRUPTION.]
ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT)
There is a sickness in this village. Perhaps you would not see it from a distance, and the faint sting of rot on the breeze is easy enough to dismiss. But as you get closer, that infectious feeling of wrongness is harder and harder to shake.

The grass is not the green of nature, the buildings are warped by more than age, and the voices that come from behind the inhabitants’ masks are hoarse and wet.

They move with exaggerated casualness, a parody of idyllic village life. And when they have a break from weeping, they reassure each other how wonderful it is in their village, or at least how wonderful it used to be.

Each is covered from head to toe in thick black fabric, and they never, ever touch.

Take a deep breath.

The air feels thick and soupy in your lungs, swarming with a thousand contagions digging into you, begging for you to join the village:

It’s so quiet there, and everyone cares for each other, far from the din and compacted flesh of the city.

In the center, a maypole stands, mildewed strips of colored cloth hanging limply from it like shreds of ragged skin. The base of the pole is ashen and charred.

The disease itself is nothing special. It begins as a small patch of discolored skin, the tiniest blemish. Scrub it off, and it is gone! For a few hours, at least. But it returns again and again, and begins to spread, a mold with tendrils that burrow deep.

It ranges in color from rancid yellow and corpse-fat white to the dull, angry purple of a fresh bruise. It itches, and burns, and you can feel it growing and spreading inside you, looking for the core of you. At least until it worms its way into your bones.

Beneath the coat of each terrified citizen of this sick village lies a lurking possibility, a nightmarish suspicion of infectious constellations of hungry mildew, a mutating technical atlas of rotten and pockmarked flesh.

But who can know for sure? Their coats are oh, so thick.

There was never a time before the disease, no matter what the old bastards tell you. It has always been in the village, always festered in the dark corners where no one could stomach to check. Where good neighbors wouldn’t dream to speculate.

But those who live here will tell you different. From behind their masks those friendly voices will tell you how it used to be: clean, and hygenic, and always bathed in sepia sunshine. They know in the guts of them this sickness has come from outside, that it is those from beyond the village that have done this to them.

They brought it here, they whisper to each other in the unnamed pub, hunched and bloated over their pale and stinking beers, lifting their masks to take a mouthful, puce faces and frightened sneers exposed for just a moment.

They couldn’t leave us well enough alone. They wanted what we have, our perfect peaceful life, and so they dragged their sickness here and damned us all.

The patrons speak quietly, ‘cause who can say for sure if the face behind a mask is a good, honest village face - or a sickness-bearing harbinger from beyond?

And people do still come to the village, for however thick the paranoia, however terrible the disease, there are worse things beyond.

They are stopped, of course. Beaten and stripped and checked head to toe for any sign of infection. The village council sees to that. Most are uncontaminated, though that does little to save them, while others are already laced right through with fungus of their own.

A few are spared brutality, and treated with such cordial politeness you must have thought their inquisitors old friends. Though there seems on the surface no rhyme to such decisions, were you to look below their coats, you might see the patterns of their mold were matched.

It is, alas, those who are unblemished who suffer worst. So incomprehensible is it that any from outside could be clean, that there might be another source or vector, the inspectors devise another theory: An invisible infection. A hundred Typhoid Marys spreading mildew and decay.

They keep them in the post office, wrapped in chicken wire, prodded and jeered and watched. Should they begin to show signs of the rot, then maybe, just maybe, they can stay for now, though nobody will doubt that it was they brought the illness.

But if they stay clean, if they continue to act like they are better, like they are above the sickness that it is certain that they must have brought to the village, then that cannot be endured. So they are taken to the village green, and the scorch marks at the base of the maypole get darker.

The villagers stand on the green to watch, ignoring the bending of the grass as it tries to worm its way through their boots. They watch the screaming outsider as the fire purifies them, and inside feel the gnawing panic of their own secrets.

For how long ago did they really come to the village? How deep did their roots go? Do any of them truly remember? What if they are an outsider? What if they’re found out?

No. Such fears are to be quashed and swallowed; they must stand strong; they must stand together as one body against the mass of those beyond the village who would see them degraded and destroyed. They cannot allow such secret terrors to break their unity.

And the maypole watches over all.

There is no house in town that has not found itself marked with the red cross of plague, but paint is fleeting and the villagers are so desperate to hide their state. Night still falls here, if only to give those that wish it a chance to try and hide their frantic denials.

As the weak dawn breaks, you may count the doors now painted white, and see who is more conscientious in covering their spongy skin.

The deception is pitiable, and yet deep down every villager knows the mold has marked them deeper than any of the others, and carries it as their most secret shame.

Foremost in their denials are the village council, those loud and hardy souls who have taken it upon themselves to police this place, to safeguard their traditions and denounce the infection that is the right and proper punishment of those who would allow the village borders to be breached, and their ancient way of life to be compromised.

Their masks are blue and red and white, and their coats are the color of fresh ivory, stained sometimes with streaks of crimson from their dutiful ministrations. None would dare accuse them of infection, and to cross them or draw their eye is to invite the strongest diagnosis.

Head of the council is Jillian Smith. Her father’s father’s father’s father’s father built the maypole, carved from a jackalberry tree and painted in the colors of the village. This place is her home and her right and her duty, and woe to any fungus-riddled outsider who might believe it otherwise.

For no one would speak up if Jillian Smith were to mark you infected or declare you foreign. No one would lift a finger as they dragged you to the green.

Her gloves are purest white and never sullied, and they hide a cerulean mold that covers every inch of her, through skin, muscle, and organ, though she has no idea it runs so deep.

By night, she sits in the quiet darkness of her perfect cottage, peeling herself with a straight razor, layer by layer, desperate to reach the pure flesh she is so sure must still be in there, somewhere.

Her living room is the same suffocation blue as the rest of her, every surface piled high with her own discarded bloody skin, and she has no terror deeper than the thought she might be discovered. As she pulls spongy strips free one agonizing fiber at a time, she stares from the window at the house of her neighbor, Mrs Kim.

Mrs Kim is not on the village council. Mrs Kim keeps to herself. And Jillian Smith is certain Mrs Kim is not infected, and hates her for it.

What Mrs Kim is, is scared. Scared of her neighbors, scared of her friends, scared of the moment when someone will smell the spreading patch of darkness on her back, and decide she is infected, or remember she has only been in the village since her grandfather’s day, and judge her to be an outsider.

Should she accuse someone else? Send them to the village green? Perhaps she might petition to join the village council, though that would invite their attention as much as anything might.

Even through the masks, Mrs Kim knows the looks she gets in the pub. But what can she do?

When she hears the shouts outside and sees the smoke pouring from the thatch roof, she knows it is too late.

They drag her to the maypole, their masks hiding the tears of terror and angry shame, and lash her there with those strips of cloth that never seem to burn.

Mrs Kim does not fight, though she screams and screams and screams as all her fears are realized. Jillian Smith tries to smile as she watches her neighbor burn, but the fungus is too thick around her lips, and her face no longer moves.

As the flames consume the last of Mrs Kim in thick and acrid smoke, the mold reaches the bones of Jillian Smith, and she blooms.

In a moment she is swollen, bloated, bursting into a cloud of violet spores that envelop the green and those who dwell there, embracing them in a rot that long since seeped into the soil of this blighted land.

ARCHIVIST:
Recorded direct from subject.

RATNER (STATEMENT):
Alright… Sure.

Where do you want me to start?

My name is Alan Ratner and I had been dating… well, I mean, I’m not a…

The thing is I’ve never really felt love before. I’ve never really felt anything more than I did then. I’ve never felt anything quite as intensely since. It was the longest month of my life, and part of me wants desperately to get this out somewhere, to make some kind of… peace.

The problem was twofold. The first was that I did not love her. I’ve never been happy with other people and… in my heart, I always knew they were better than me. But a long way from happiness, I was left with this sinking feeling inside me: “I’m never going to have anyone. I’m never going to have anyone.”

The second was a feeling was sharp in my chest: the need to be loved.

So, the only person who has ever loved me was dead. I felt so very foreign. Like I’m not even human. Like I’m something that has no right to be here. In a way, not being human is exactly what I needed. I’ll try not to think about it too much. It’s… it’s been rough, but… I just hope that maybe it’s not too much to keep going. I really don’t want to die alone.

Well… thank you.

ARCHIVIST:
Statement ends.

Er…

[Sigh] Sorry, I didn’t, er…

I, I didn’t know that.

Statement of Peter Lukas, regarding why in the name of all that is scary he fell in love with Jonah Magnus of all people/monsters.

PETER (STATEMENT):
My parents… didn’t love me, exactly. They always used to say that there was nothing so dreadful as a little stranger in their home. But Jonah Magnus was different. He was a curious man, with a genuine fondness for the macabre, and he would talk to me of a future that was so bright for both of us. He was strange, but he had a kindness to him that I’d never seen before.

His ideas on love were few and far between. His philosophy was that of the sort of love one would expect from a conjured creature, it should be unconditional and all-consuming, one that would last a lifetime.

From the outside, I find it hard to understand how that all-consuming devotion to my relationship with him, combined with the impracticality of it all, could possibly produce such a result. But it did.

He was exactly the sort of guy I wanted to spend my life with. But the closer the relationship developed, the more I saw that it was far beyond what I had bargained for.

Well, the kiss was nothing like any of my…, um, fantasies. It was solid. It was unscripted. It was perhaps a bit abrupt, I, I thought it was quite out of character for the kind of thing that, uh, maybe he -

MICHAEL
Article 33 of the liner, or ‘Project Mayhem’. Apparently, the dissolution of the International Brigades, and the formation of a new organisation, the Sons of Horus, based on the principles of the old Warhammer Fantasy book, though the name changed hands several times. Michael was said to be the first to use the new name, although no details were given.

Apparently, the dissolution of the IAF, the British Expeditionary Force, in May of ‘45, and the creation of the Sons of Horus in June of that year, was the turning point in the history of the Imperial Fists. They would be renamed the Imperial Legion, later the Imperial Army, and eventually the Imperial Police. They would be headquartered in Alexandria, in North Africa, and trained in the Imperial Fists regimental depot, but over the next few years would start to move up towards the front, to conduct operations in the field. It was at this point in the journal that Michael became involved.

He had been listening intently, though not paying any attention to my words. When I mentioned the journal to him, he grabbed the book in a swift gesture and handed it over. I took it, and his face fell, and he turned to me with a slight smirk. He said something about the value of my services, and how much time I’d saved him. Apparently, I’d learned of a legionnaire’s funeral pyre from Napoleon III, who had just passed away, and that was how the old man had begged me to get him another one. I told him so, and he nodded, as though he’d been just as surprised as me, and mumbled something else. It was only when I asked if I could see his body after he died that he revealed it. He was carrying a rolled up brown paper bag, and it was full of snake skin.

Statement of Jon regarding love

ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT):
Love finds its way into all of existence, whether we like it or not. Whether we realize it or not. The concept of it is deeply ingrained in the very DNA of humanity. It is a concept that can be likened to the ineffable unity that we all share, which is so deeply felt that the words that describe it are not always ones that can to be spoken. I know it’s easy to forget, to give into the void, until you find yourself in a place where you can no longer survive, because you give no thought to the trillions of other beings that lie between you and the void.

How much do you know about the Big Bang?

It was dark space. It had been for some time. All that was was hot, empty nothing. But not for long. A sudden bright spot broke the otherwise frozen universe, and it pulled into a ball of blazing energy. And then the gravitation of the dark universe stretched it out into a being: a being that loves you.

The warmth of a sun that still rises and sets its own radiance so bright and penetrating that you could feel the it through your own skin.

The very universe itself, the very fabric of reality itself, is love.

ARCHIVIST:
Statement ends.

MARTIN:
That’s… that’s quite nice, isn’t it?

ARCHIVIST:
Mm.

Statement of David Atayah, regarding his relationship with James Grice up until he moved out of their shared flat.

DAVID (STATEMENT):
It’s hard to put my relationship with James into words. It was… strange. I’ve never really written anything down, and now I do, because I feel it’s important that you understand what it’s like.

By my late twenties, I had drifted away from my mother and was on the path to what I would consider adulthood. As I got older, my circle of friends expanded, I was more afraid of dying alone than I was of death.

You must have read about his death in the paper. He was a good friend of mine, and we’d met through a mutual mutual friend. James was a tall man, with a kind, round face and deep rumpled brown hair. He was quite the curiosity, so I decided to take him out for coffee to warm up. I don’t know what came over me as I stirred it. As he sipped his coffee, there was this look in his eyes that I had never seen on any of my other friend’s eyes before.

Something about this grotty little apartment building, above ground, with its stained walls. I loved it, because I could see the the courtyard, and everything was so little down there. It was only after James’s death that I realized it might not have been as cosy as I thought it had been. The building was far too small for anyone to live there, and every time I passed the window, I got vertigo.

DAISY (STATEMENT):
Love conquers the world; it brings people through their darkest hours, and makes them what they are. It gives them meaning, and makes them what they are. It’s the reason we’re here, and it’s the reason I’m here, and it’s the reason I’m going to let you in on this.

Statement of Elias Bouchard, regarding the time his husband Peter Lukas was turned into a rubber duck.

ELIAS (STATEMENT):
My first thought was that my marriage to Peter Lukas had ended in incompatibility, as seems to have been the case with most of his marriages. Later, I realized that’s not the case, and I am sadly mistaken. As far as I can tell, he has shown no interest in seeing me, despite the fact that we were living together when our brief engagement ended. He has also shown no interest in my son Marcus, despite the fact that he spent almost his entire life with him. He made it abundantly clear that if he was unhappy with my parenting style, he was not going to be happy when I decided to start juggling. I’ll admit, it didn’t please him that I was raising my own son, but he seemed to have no interest in actually understanding.

Still, there was something about this baby that unsettled me. As he toddled and walked, slowly but steadily. Never taking my eyes off the baby. This… something in the way he moved… disturbed me. I do not believe that anyone will be turning into a rubber duck anytime soon.

I’ve always been told that babies are hard. No, they’re soft. In fact, the word ‘cute’ comes to mind when thinking about babies. My husband, of course was the first to point this out. He told me that babies are cute. I could never bring myself to tell him he was wrong, or point out that it was probably untrue.


Hi my name is Ebony Dark'ness Dementia Raven Way and I have long ebony black hair (that's how I got my name) with purple streaks and red tips that reaches my mid-back and icy blue eyes like limpid tears and a lot of people tell me I look like Amy Lee (AN: if u don't know who she is get da hell out of here!). I'm not related to Gerard Way but I wish I was because he's a major fucking hottie. I'm a vampire but my teeth are straight and white. I have pale white skin. I'm also a witch, and I go to a

lot of rituals.

I’m not a stranger to these things, but I was very new to it all, and there were a few others wearing the mark. A particularly awful one was Nikos Anastos, who I think was half-brother to Gerard, or so his sister says. I didn’t know her name back then, though obviously I now know who she is and what she wants. She was a weird one, you know. Psycho, half-giant, who secretly hated both his parents for not being enough to instill in him the love of the vampire. I’ll, I’ll admit it, I got a bit wrapped up in all the communal niceties and he’d saved the world in ways he wasn’t even aware of. But he was alive and well, so I put him to death for it. Which, I guess, means I get a lot of grief back.

I wasn’t quite ready to put a stop to it, though. I’d killed one of the others and there was no going back, not really. I hadn’t prepared for the possibility of return, but something wouldn’t let me just sit idly by and wait. So I got to work.

I don’t know how much you know about the occult, what Kieran Craig called “the great taboo” back in 2014. But the Templars are not your grandparents’s bloodsucking cult; they’re your, er, your salvation. They bring you into the fold, and if you don’t help them, they bring you into confusion and even death. And they do this for a reason. The more you know about them, the more you understand why they’re here, and why you’re part of their wider ritual.

Statement of Timothy Stoker regarding his brother Danny. Statement begins.

Statement of Martin Blackwood, regarding his love for Archivist Jonathan Sims.

MARTIN (STATEMENT):
Why do you need me to live it over again?

I loved him. I mean, what else is there? I loved him so much, so much that sometimes I worried he might not be able to love me back the same.

But I think he did. I think he always did. In many ways he made me more myself.

At least, that’s how I would like it to be.

I don’t know if it was love, or if it was just longing. These days, it’s mostly just waiting. For some reason, it feels so good to simply wait, to just be alright for a while. For any good that can come from this - well it’s probably not going to come for a while.

I - I, I feel like I’m falling into something, like I’m losing myself. Like I’m on some sort of knife’s edge, and I have to keep steadying myself, because if I fall off the edge I don’t know.

And when I do fall…

MARTIN:
Well, good night, Jon.

MARTIN:
Statement ends.

Statement of Bernard Montgomery regarding her life

Statement begins.

ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT):
I should not have returned to the archive. I should have stayed in my room and burned all the tapes. I knew I was going to die alone. Even before the nightmares began.

I should have destroyed the place. If I know what I’m doing, then I believe the best that it might do is merely delay the inevitable. But I’m trapped here, as it were. And I do not want to die alone. I do not want to fade away.

I know I will not be missed. I know I will be forgotten. But something still rushes through me, curling and staining and itching, and I am there, I am aching. I have a dream that I see a pale, pointed star, in a small clearing in the jungle. I go there, and I dream again. I dream of grass and leaves across that vast, roling field. I dream of bloodshed and death. And when I reach the spot, then the star turns to face me and grows blinding.

I don’t know how long I lay there. Waiting for dawn to catch me. I am tired, and I am sick, and I have a suspicion that I shall one day die. And then I shall awake, and see the jungle again.

ARCHIVIST:
Statement ends.

Well, this makes me… deeply unhappy. I’ll try to be more specific. I’m thinking of the death of Mr. Montgomery. I am especially concerned that she may have had serious mental health issues. Everything can’t be true, can it? There is nothing and nothing and nobody, there is only…

Mr. Montgomery died on April 7th, 2013, near Alexandria, Virginia. He was found dead at his home. According to the autopsy, it was due to a rise in carbon monoxide levels that may have contributed to her death. There is no mention of whether this was accidental or not.

pronouncingitwang
Statement of Alan Ratner regarding Greg Mann's death

RATNER (STATEMENT):
I should have known. I’d known. What little control I still had over my own actions seemed to wane with each new instance of mundane fear. I know how it sounds, but Mann was my friend. I loved him. I still do. He was soft-spoken and smiled like no one on earth. I have sometimes wondered whether I could have done anything to stop what happened. How, if I had known what was happening, it was possible that Greg would not have died.

It was the second of May when he died. I remember vividly that night in particular. I was in the basement when I heard it. There was the sound of something growling, kind of like a wild animal. It scared me so badly that I had to get out of the room quickly. I looked for an escape, but couldn’t see anything. I ran into the adjacent hall, closing the door behind me. It was then that I saw it.

It was bent over the body of my friend. It was hard to make out any details. When it opened it’s eyes, I could tell it was not human. I could make out a long, thin figure. The legs were long, too long. It was very thin, and had a sort of vicious bent to it. It dragged the rest of the body behind it, and opened its mouth to reveal long, sharp teeth. Then it began to speak, clearly: “I’m sorry.”

Statement of Jonathan Sims regarding how exactly he fell in love with Martin Blackwood. Statement recorded direct from subject... Statement begins.

ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT):

Well, this has, uh… Well, this has been a strange one. I’ve been in love with Martin Blackwood for, for almost a year now. The first time I knew was during a visit to his flat in, in London. It, it was like there was a door in my heart, and it had been slowly opening since I met him. I went for months and months without ever really considering it, until I found myself there in his house.

I should have realized sooner. But it was too late for those thoughts, and the pure joy that I felt from his company made me forget those thoughts. I love him so much, and he makes me feel so whole. I left that house so different.

From that moment on, everything I’ve done has been for him.


statement of martin blackwood, regarding his first date with jon sims

MARTIN (STATEMENT)
Okay, so it’s really happened.

I’m sure you don’t need me to tell you how strange it was to fall in love. I’ve never really given much thought to it, really. My parents didn’t love each other, my aunts and uncles didn’t really love each other, and so forth. But once I met my friend Jon, it… it changed all of that. I’d never been in a relationship before. But I’d been friends with Jon for a while, and it’d been great, because he’d Read more of my stuff than I did, and it felt good to be liked. It felt good to be wanted.

He’d even stop by my flat when I was in, once to read a few pages of my work, and when I headed into the hall he’d be waiting for me.

Now, this was years ago, probably as far back as 1982, and if he hadn’t known about it, he probably wouldn’t have… asked me to do some preliminary work with him. So, he turns up, and does some work. And it’s got a lot of really nasty stuff at the core, so he’s definitely headed in the right direction.

It appears to be a fault system. There are several other similar systems in the area. One day, underground, Bryan Shaw and I were going to extract some rocks from below ground, and, and there he is. The tunnel caves, and he’s gone.

The scars on my hands don’t heal. They follow me wherever I go, and if I run, I can feel the hot grip of earth on my hands, like a vice around my neck. “They are the hidden hand of the Pit,” I say, and there is nothing to prove to the contrary.

Well, I ran. I, I don’t know how far, but I ran, and I’m here. Here, in this place, you can see all the things. All the things that are here, are made of stone. They walk through this place, and if you, if you look really hard, you can see them. If you, if you look really hard, you can reach out into the vast, dark void beyond the rock, and you’d find them there. If you, if you look really hard, you can see them in the few seconds it takes me to reach you.

And if you, if you look really hard, you can see them in the light, swaying below me. They are the shadows. Thin, branching black lines, stretching away to the horizon. The future’s not where it should be, but I’m running towards something I don’t know if I should be running towards.

And as I reach out, I am hit by a sudden wave of… rage? Or perhaps something softer, like panic? I know, I am, I’m well aware of how late this is, but I still can’t name it. Help? I feel a surge of rage approaching, building towards something terrible. And I scream.

Statement of Dick Baltierra regarding his relationship with Jonah Magnus

MARTIN (STATEMENT)
My story, like so many of his, is full of paradoxes. I don’t believe in God, for one. I still can’t name any gods I love more than he, and if I was truly his – if I was his as I loved him, then – Well, anyway, Jonah Magnus was clearly more of a god than a man. I mean, I guess you could call it whatever you want, but it wasn’t anything as simple as that.

I loved him, though. He was everything I dreamed he would be. I could never figure out if it was me, him, or something. It didn’t matter, of course, not really. If I loved him, then he had to be some kind of god. He should have died, and I would not wish that on anyone. But he didn’t. Instead, he built a temple to himself.

Evening. It was very quiet that night. It seemed to me that, as the hours turned into days, the people I had thought I knew least had begun to change with them, those I had come to know and admire, had begun to change as well. It was not clear whether it was night or day, but it was nearly dark when I went in, and the dim lights made me think of nothing at all.

The floor was slippery with dust and mildew. There was no light coming from inside, but I checked the inside of the room, and sure enough, there was light. I didn’t realise the presence of other adults in the room, but I turned on my torch and shone it around.

By this point, whatever I had thought of as the bedroom was in the process of being stripped away. There was a thick, black dusting of mildew. The light didn’t reach far enough to see by, but I was glad of it.

Dust began to pour from the opening door, and I was glad I was only just then taking it out. I could hear the faint sound of movement from further in, but when I turned on the light, I could see the face of the person I had met before. Their wide, smiling eyes were round and staring.

archivistbot:

Hi everyone! It’s me again, your mod, Joel “rabid fox trapped in a whole foods” Macky.
Since this blog was made during the break, I just want to share some information and guidelines for the new season. This blog is not spoiler-free and will continue to post anything spoiler-y people send in untagged, but please try to wait a considerate amount of time, let’s say, two days after the episode comes out for non-patreon listeners, before sending asks relating to the episode. In addition to this, I will not be training the bot on each episode as the transcripts are written. It will have all of them eventually, but if, for example, a new character is introduced, the bot won’t know about them right away.
That’s all! Thank you all very much for sticking around. Wishing you light and joy in these times. Stay safe!

Let’s get one thing straight right now. No, I’m not going to touch with the philosophical underpinnings of decay. Not really. Let’s just say that any statement you find here that deals with the topic is, at its heart, wrong. Because it deals with things that are not inside of time. thank you anondo you determine the beginning of the night shift on a night-to-night basis...? is it a ceremony
ARCHIVIST
It’s difficult to say. Certainly not in terms of day or night. Some people designate a night as its own, others as its time-frame, but it’s not always clear when either is referring to it. In some ways, the word ‘night’ is confusing, as it can mean one thing in the daytime, when the universe continues, it could mean one thing in the night, when the universe simply does not exist.

It doesn’t always have to be night. Sometimes it can be as early as the mid-afternoon, and as the seasons turn. But in general the duties of the night shift are pretty simple. Unless, of course, your employer has assigned them completely differently, and you’re the only person responsible for night shift hours.

Statement of Hesper regarding being kicked out of the Royal Society after running an unofficial sting operation on behalf of the London Anarchist Bookfair.
HESTER (STATEMENT)
I’ve been with the library since it first opened. Since then, there’s nothing that can top the feeling of being on the edge of something.

There’s something about these books, something you just can’t help but feel. I like to think that they contain some deeper truths, little by little unveiling the unconscious fears and secrets of the world to come.

But I think that’s a double-edged sword. On the one hand, you reveal all sorts of disturbing truths about the people you deal with, but on the other, you keep reinforcing those same things, making them part of your self, making them part of your routine. If there’s one advantage to working inside a library, it’s that we have an endless supply of carefully selected books, each one carefully labelled with its story, its subject, and a thousand or so words describing how it was that put them there.

I chose to work the book fair, as it was the only one that year that had a rotating cast of writers, all of whom had something of a personal relationship with my predecessor. Sometimes they’d come, sometimes they’d just be there, feeding my craft. And some of them, when they’d been written down, would leave again, and I’d assume they were simply there to direct me in my path.

This was years ago, and I’d just turned 35, but I still remember that excited voice of my friend Elias. He was so earnest, so sure I was on the path to something great. And I was, too.

My mate Hester said he was kicked out of the Royal Society a few years back for running an unofficial sting operation on behalf of the London Anarchist Bookfair, and I’d stopped long enough to ask how he’d been getting on. He just looked at me and said, “Can I have a kiss?” I told him, and he nodded, propping himself up on the elbow to show me that he knew it.

I kissed him, and it was almost painful to watch. I’m not ashamed to admit I was the one that made the first move, but he just looked at me and said, “You win.”

I had never really won, but he had certainly been weakened in the process. He had a look of such sadness in his eyes, and I was certain that he was going to cry, and I could see his mouth twist into something I would have thought was a smile. Instead, he leaned in close to me and began to kiss me. There was a touch of danger in his voice.

I felt his hand grip mine firmly, and I asked if he was alright. He shook his head violently, and told me that he was a “real bad guy.” Then he went completely still, and I left.

How do you describe the feeling of being burned at the stake? Imagine being burned, your whole body and nerves and bones being ripped from your body, and you’re left sitting there, that bitter, pungent smell in your lungs and your whole body becoming hot and mushy. God, I can only pray.

Hi everyone! It’s me again, your mod, Joel “rabid fox trapped in a whole foods” Macky.
Since this blog was made during the break, I just want to share some information and guidelines for the new season. This blog is not spoiler-free and will continue to post anything spoiler-y people send in untagged, but please try to wait a considerate amount of time, let’s say, two days after the episode comes out for non-patreon listeners, before sending asks relating to the episode. In addition to this, I will not be training the bot on each episode as the transcripts are written. It will have all of them eventually, but if, for example, a new character is introduced, the bot won’t know about them right away.
That’s all! Thank you all very much for sticking around. Wishing you light and joy in these times. Stay safe!

someBODY once told me

who turgled
A red SUV pulled up, with license plates ending in “DIRECT-”. They showed no signs of haste or hurry, and instead advanced with a brisk, if somewhat disconcerting click.

The driver, a huge man with a shaved head, advanced to the driver’s side and gave the thumbs up. The door opened, and a man stepped out, a big smile on his face. He introduced himself as Gabriel, and said he was from the RCMP, and that he was looking for a missing person. I didn’t know his name, but he clearly had something of a case.

I mean, I didn’t really know what to say, since it was clearly clear he didn’t want my help, and I had no idea where I was headed or how to proceed. He seemed to be talking about some kind of business, and I was kind of wondering if he was going to ask for any sort of assistance.

As it turned out, he was, and I had just about made my decision when he began to walk towards me. I made my way almost instinctively, since I was worried I might be crossing some kind of legal red line. I followed him. He was not tall man, but he was huge, with a frame that seemed to bulge ten percent in every direction. His arms were long, and his back was straight as an arrow.

When he saw me staring down at him, he LAUGHS. It is a soft sound, like he’s enjoying the attention. His smile is bright red, and his voice is nothing like mine.

I heard footsteps approaching the door. There is a high-pitched, whirring sound, which I assume is coming from the inside. I followed Gabriel into the room behind him, and it became clear he was not interested in talking. I started to ask if he was alright, but as I asked, he just laughed, and pushed me to the side.

Instead of answering, he said something else. It was in a voice so low it almost sounded like a whisper. He said, “We are not what we appear to be.”

Books are amazing, aren’t they? I mean, when you think about what they really are. People don’t give the actuality of language the weight it deserves, I feel. Words are a way of taking your thoughts, the very make-up of yourself, and giving them to another. Putting your thoughts in the mind of someone else. They are not a perfect method, of course, as there’s plenty of scope for mutation and corruption between your mind and that of the listener, but that doesn’t change the essence of what language is.

Spoken aloud, though, the thought dies quickly if not picked up. Simple vibrations that vanish almost as soon as they are created, though if they find a host, then they can lodge there, proliferate, and maybe spread further. A book, though, is another story.

mod, do you take the time to make sure answers dont contradict canon or previous asks, or does the bot somehow know not to say something different about a character when asked a second time?

So, I guess a little bit of both!

Statement of John Amherst, regarding a baffling romantic encounter. Statement recorded direct from subject 6th September, 1992. Statement begins.
STATEMENT GIVER (STATEMENT)
Well, it’s been a hard couple of weeks. (laugh) I’m, I’m really not feeling well. I’m, I’m sure it’s because of - you know, this sort of thing. The feeling that something’s not right. Like it’s not a dream, or, or it’s not me. It just… there’s something not right about it. Like my legs are weak, and I’m falling apart. And I can’t… I just can’t move. I can’t, I can’t get out of bed, I keep passing out in front of everyone, and then I wake up in the night, and I see the ants. And I feel them move along the floor, along the corridor, make their slow, circuitous journey towards me.

Whatever it is, it feels like they’re going to move their way along the wall, until they reach the other end, and then they are gone. I am trapped. And I hate this. If there was, if there was a door, something, anything, then I could get out of there. But there is nothing, and I just want to stay here. I don’t want to leave. And if this is the price I have to pay, then so be it.

You’ve got to understand, I have so much to keep track of, so… I, I started counting the seconds, because I’m running out of petrol, and, and I just couldn’t stand the sound of that awful grinding, and… and the empty hive.

I’m not a beekeeper, you know. No, I am not one of those people who dedicate their life to the struggle against the insect hordes, the swarm, the nothing that waits for the next step. I am one of those people who have a, a duty, an obligation to watch out for, a, a warning that comes only when the overseer is nearby. There are, there are very few cases where a swarm, or a swarm of insects, is actually dangerous.

I was watching that grove of trees, though, as it was late spring and the chill had begun to hit.

I ran up to the grove of trees, and, and I was surprised to see that, as I approached, the whole tree seemed to be covered in buzzing insects.

The grove of trees was entirely composed of them, and each hive was surrounded by a small enclosure of trees, each hive a distinct tree, its own small enclosure. There was no smell of honey. The tree hollows were lined with dirt and slick with insect faeces, and could be clearly seen under the most intense of sunlight.

Glaring down through the trees I saw the researchers entering one of the hollows.

does the archivistbot answer indirect questions about itself differently than questions it is asked directly? it seems like if I ask “archivistbot” a question directly it will be answered in character, but when the archivistbot is mentioned indirectly it says something weirdly sentient.
When you ask a question to or about archivistbot it’s usually interpreted as part of dialogue so it has a character answer it. When you say something about it, it’s often read as part of a statement or longer piece of text which is why there’s no character attributed to it, I just can’t articulate that in this format.



So yes, sort of!

Statement of Sonny Bower, after a night of hard drinking in the Californian desert.

After dark in the rolling fields, it’s a wild place, and in the middle of the sand dunes, where the highlands meet the sea, there are these strange dreams.

You know, I like to think I’m being hunted, but I have no idea that’s actually the case. I mean, looking at all the weapons stores in this place, I sort of doubt that.

He takes the foot of the counter, turns the light on, and sits down. He is, I’m sure, a disgusting man. Hardly able to stand, with a life vest mass grinding against his fragile thigh, and a cloth pendant clutched in his hand.

The regular customer doesn’t even look at me when I get the receipt, which is always near. He doesn’t look at the register, which I assume is somewhere secret, he just takes the door and wanders aimlessly looking for a copy of the dailies, or the pilot.

The sky is grey. The hour is late, and the wind is howling. The regular customer is dead.

Statement of The Henhouse regarding The Henhouse

I found it in the heat of the sun,

And in the silence of the mist-sweet air;

And in the rapture of the skies,

The calm amid the ashes.

It was thy will that drew me here,

And made you an offering;

Thy will that holds me fast,

And makes you a pledge to never leave your path.

Though you may travel far,

I will stay, pledge, if it brings you much comfort;

Though you may travel far,

I will stay, pledge, if it brings you much peace.

Though you may travel far,

I will stay, pledge, if it brings you much rest.


Statement of Owen regarding the Henhouse

OWEN (STATEMENT): 
There is a strange friendship a man may form with a goose.

I’ll not go into the particulars of his goose, for I could not describe this thing, neither human nor beast. It could not properly have been a bird. I was so large that my arms would be hard pressed to encompass its whole mass. Surely that should give you an idea of its size.

I fed the goose once, when he visited my estate, and it had returned again for more. I was not the only one that time, and it has almost single-handedly depleted my stock of fruit, ham, and other victuals.

Such is the life of Owen Palumbo.

EDUARD (STATEMENT): 
Where do you want me to start? Growing up? My people? My dreams?

I grew up in a small house just outside of Moscow. It wasn’t very nice, but I had plenty of second-hand books, and I was surrounded by my siblings.

My memories of my childhood are, to put it generously, not very good. I was one of the youngest, and though I had good grades, and plenty of friends, day after day, job after job, there was never enough to make me happy. I started suspect it was something to do with me. That I was to blame for my empty and pointless existence.

It wasn’t that I felt any great sadness or despair at this; no, it was that I felt nothing.

I graduated with a degree from Medical School, higher than any other student, but it was clear that nothing would bring me happiness.

I applied to various programmes, but none of the available positions seemed to offer me what I’d spent my entire youth searching for. I returned to my village for a few years to try and explain to my parents why I was going back to my village, but they were deeply ashamed of me, and didn’t seem to have any interest in my life.

I don't feel empty anymore, though.


EDUARD (STATEMENT): 
My parents were the worst. They’ve always been very religious, I’ve always had to make an effort to keep them happy. They’ve always been very materialistic, and seemed to be more concerned with their own happiness than with mine. They treated me like a china doll, not a sentient being with its own life and decisions. They took me through my entire life like a puppet, making me play the parts that I really didn’t want to - having me perform the sorts of things that, as you’ve seen, are not in the best interest of the puppet.

And it wasn’t like they got any better as I grew up. If anything, the opposite was true, as I found, growing older, until it became so dull, that I would rather die than live like that.

I’m sure you can guess what I ended up doing instead of getting hit by that bus.

What I really wanted was to be on my own, to find my own place. Looking back, I realise that what I really wanted was to be a part of something greater than myself.

Statement of Walter Henning, regarding his feelings towards The Henhouse

, taken from a letter, dated 13th of February, 1916. Audio recording by Jonathan Sims, Head Archivist of the Magnus Institute, London.

Statement begins.

ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT): 
Dear Abby,

It is my fondest wish that this message should find you in good health. I am well aware of the anger and frustration that have characterized your relationship with me, but I feel that it is important, as I draw near the end of my life, I cannot in good conscience allow myself to maintain this less than ideal cordiality between us. I hope that you will forgive me for such a foolish letter. In my old age, my vision has passed over from red to white and now I see clearly enough the futility of my old and furious resentment of you.

I have been alone in the house for about twelve years now. I would like to remind you once again that the house is a wonderful place, full of warmth and humanity, and it is my wish it will continue to be so for many more.

I should probably try and explain things to you in a more clear way. I’ve tried to keep it as brief as possible, as I find talking about death very difficult. You can certainly fill in all the blanks yourself if you like.

I have no wife, nor other family, nor have I any close friends. However, I have a home and I have a job to do.

I want to sleep. I hope that I will soon be able to rest.

Your obedient servant,

Walter Henning

ARCHIVIST: 
Yes. Well… Huh.

Henhouse, on a scale of 1 to 10, how much did you love Marcellus and Henning?

[THE HENHOUSE CREAKS.]
I cannot choose a scale on which to measure the intensity of my loves. I have a love that cannot be objectively measured. Numbers are disjointed and indignant. I find these calculations obscure the true magnitude of what I am.

My dearest Walter,

I have traveled far, far away from home, and rarely have I felt such comfort as I did in your company. Is the air purer where you live? As I traveled, I found myself drawn to groves of trees, the fruit trees, the shade of trees, as though they were some sort of sanctuary. Are there trees where you live?

I have often dreamed of it, Walter. As you would have me stay in your home to wait for the end. I fear no land could support me, as no ship could. But I will stay there, and see you again.

Oh, if it be possible, then let your peace be my peace.

Statement of Marcellus Renaud, regarding the first time Walter Henning introduced him to the Henhouse.

OWEN (STATEMENT): 
So it’s another letter. And not a long one, either. It is very small, so very careful, and very thoughtful. And it made me have to sit down, and I think I’m not able to properly stand up yet.

OWEN (STATEMENT): 
My Dear Walter,

You will forgive me, I hope, for not speaking of this to you in person, as I have been in a habit of composing letters to you anyway.

I am grateful you have invited me to share your home with you. I thought it would have been best had you confined yourself to townhouses like the rest of us, but the house is quite a special place. And in all my years of travel, I have never yet seen anything so inviting.

I should like to live like you. I should like to be like you.

I have never been in a room full of people and not been so scared that I would sooner die than be there, but here, with you… I am lucky to have a home where I can be myself.

I love you, Walter.

I’ve been so sick, so full of doubt, and now I look at you, and I know I will get well.

Yours in trust,

OWEN: 
Mmm.

[HE SIGHS.]
OWEN (CONT’D): 
Well. I suppose we should probably let that sink in for now. Let the… the dust settle down a bit, and maybe I will get some sleep.

[HE SIGHS AGAIN.]
OWEN: 
Yeah. (to himself) Okay.

[HE OPENS THE DOOR AND LEAVES.]
OWEN: 
Yeah. (shaky half-laugh) Okay.

Dearest Henning,

How have you been? I’m not sure how much longer I can stand to be away from you. I hope you’re well. I find it difficult to sleep, much of my life is driven by hunger and fear, and I find it very difficult to concentrate, much less to write.

I have been thinking of you often, and this morning I had the most terrifying dream of this vast, roiling sea, stretching out in all directions as far as I could see.

I know I have been touched by something terrible, and I should withdraw into the warm embrace of earth soon. I look up at the sky once again and cannot help but grieve. In the distance, I see clouds forming near the horizon. It may take many years to come to fruition. But when it does, then what will you do?

You’ve been so sweet to me, and I feel the deepest gratitude to you, but I know you’re not for me. You are like the ship, and I, your Jonah. Whatever happens, it will be my doing.

You are too good, and your kisses are too soft. I love you, and I am sorry I never had the courage to truly love you. But maybe that’s okay. You deserve better.

With love,

Your devoted servant,

Marcellus

Henhouse, did people used to sing a lot around you? Back when Henning and Marcellus were around?

[LOW BACKGROUND NOISE]
Long was I silent. I don’t know how long it was before it happened. I heard the singing, though, from somewhere in the darkness. It was a song of some sort, but I could not place it. It was so familiar, yet so far from anything I had ever imagined.

The song was new, and I was young. I could not have been over the age of twenty. I remember it so clearly. The glow of the candles on the wall and the soft singing voices.

I thought: “This must be love.”

It was not a feeling I had expected.

I must have missed you.

Dear Mr. Henning,

On the subject of your invitation to join you, I fear I must decline. the depths of winter are a cruel beast, it would be a grave error to leave the warmth of my home. Statement of Walter Henning, regarding his feelings towards The Henhouse, taken from a letter, dated 13th of February, 1916. Audio recording by Jonathan Sims, Head Archivist of the Magnus Institute, London.

Statement begins.

ARCHIVIST (STATEMENT): 
Dear Abby,

It is my fondest wish that this message should find you in good health. I am well aware of the anger and frustration that have characterized your relationship with me, but I feel that it is important, as I draw near the end of my life, I cannot in good conscience allow myself to maintain this less than ideal cordiality between us. I hope that you will forgive me for such a foolish letter. In my old age, my vision has passed over from red to white and now I see clearly enough the futility of my old and furious resentment of you.

I have been alone in the house for about twelve years now. I would like to remind you once again that the house is a wonderful place, full of warmth and humanity, and it is my wish it will continue to be so for many more.

I should probably try and explain things to you in a more clear way. I’ve tried to keep it as brief as possible, as I find talking about death very difficult. You can certainly fill in all the blanks yourself if you like.

I have no wife, nor other family, nor have I any close friends. However, I have a home and I have a job to do.

I want to sleep. I hope that I will soon be able to rest.

Your obedient servant,

Walter Henning

ARCHIVIST: 
Yes. Well… Huh.

henhouse, were you made to love or did someone teach you how?

You know, thinking about it, the mere idea that there are things out there that are not made to love is laughable in my opinion.

I’ve always been, then, an optimist. I believe in the potential for love in all things. Whether it be physical, such as the warmth and joy of a fire, or emotional, such as the quiet understanding of another being. Whether it arises from within or from without, it does not matter to me. What is important is that it is always possible, I have never looked for it and not seen it, and I believe that to deny this possibility is to deny the basic premise of your being.

Statement of Simon Renaud regarding the death of Mariana Hersh

It was the middle of the night when I heard it, and I went downstairs to investigate.

I had been up all night, and had not had the energy to go back to sleep. I crept towards the door. As I approached, I heard something, the sound of something being dragged. It was a heavy, thumping sort of sound. When I reached the threshold I saw a faint movement on the wall, then I heard a voice, crisp and clear, whispering. It said, “Open the door.”

I slammed the door shut, and got out. I was just about to go back in - but I felt a sudden surge of terror come over me as I heard the heavy footsteps approach. The door opened and there stood Mr. Mortimer. I asked him what was going on, and he just stared at me, then closed the door.

I didn’t like that he’d shut the door, didn’t like that he’d done that. But I didn't imagine… (shaky half-laugh) I certainly didn’t expect him to-

I have faced the possibility of my life being meaningless. I think that’s okay. Not everything that happens must mean something, or can be measured. We’re all just meaningless particles, running around in meaningless circles, doing pointless things. There’s beauty in the messy chaos of nature. Nature is made of tiny and perfectly designed atoms, there is no grand or grand moral significance to them, they just are. Sometimes, if I am very quiet, I can feel the absence of everything, see the empty universe, and love it for its strangeness.

If you believe in a grand universal plan, you might reject all of this, right? You might say that everything is causally determined, and thus can’t be truly meaningless. I say to you that you are only half right. The facts are this: there are living, breathing, sentient beings in this universe, and they are suffering. They have free will, but they are subject to random, meaningless, and cruel fates. They do not suffer because of their own will. They do not deserve it.

Statement of Meaty, also known as James Grice, regarding their nightmares

MEATY (STATEMENT): 
My bedroom’s warm now, but the nightmares are still there. They follow me wherever I go. There’s a sharpness to them; I can’t put them into words. My mind will narrow and twist into grotesque shapes, and I’ll always be haunted by them. How do you describe suffering? Without end? You can’t. Not really.

They follow me wherever I go, though they no longer have any sort of destination. They are not black and white, but shift between one extreme and another with startling speed. I am no longer sure what I’m looking at, and if I try to remain perfectly still, I worry I might be seen.

My nightmares are of a violent nature. The images are not ones of carnage, of war, of bloodshed. They are rather those of disorder and confusion, of impossible causality, of utterly indifferent causes. The violence is not mine, but I am powerless within it.

I have a reoccurring dream of my house burning down. A terrible inferno of destruction and fire, a dwelling that catches fire from the inside, and soon I too am caught up in it. In a way, it’s not even a nightmare.

ARCHIVIST: 
Statement ends.

MEATY: 
Fuck you, Jonathan.

ARCHIVIST: 
Thank you. Just Jon is fine, though.

Statement of Meaty, also known as James Grice, regarding their experience with being hunted by hunters.

MEATY (STATEMENT): 
I never liked hide-and-seek. I like it even less when it’s… like this.

That’s not to say that I’m not good at hiding. I’ve always been good at hiding. Mostly.

But this… it feels so different. I don’t like being hunted. I mean, I still get a bit frightened when I hear the sound of a gun or a gun-wielding person on tv.

Me hiding from them - it was years ago, in the summer of 2016. I was on “holiday“ in Barcelona when I started to feel like I was being followed.

So, I thought, “Maybe they’re after me,” but I didn’t have any reason to think that they were.

Then I heard the gunshots. There was more of a rumble, I think, and then the shots rang out even louder. And then I felt it: the hot feeling of a bullet hole in your head. I’d just been thinking, “They’re not for me.” They were.

There was a man next to me. He was not a man. I began to stagger backwards, thinking “What the hell”. I remember I spun around, but he wasn’t looking at me. He had his rifle pointed at me, and it was pointed right at my head, and he did not look me in the eye before he fired again.

I tried to get their death certificate fixed, but they refused to go with me, saying they didn’t want to pay for my grief. Um. They’ve changed a lot, though. They’re quieter, now, more careful. I’ve learned to cope with it. With meals, with hugs, and sleep. It’s the best I can offer.

There are times when I wish they wouldn’t be silent. Gripped by nightmares, or shaken by terrible visions, they’re just as silent as ever. Shaking.

I’ve always been in love with Meaty. I’ll always be in love with Meaty.

Anyway, I’m just going to go back to sleep. Keep the nightmares away, maybe read a book, make them feel safe.

Your humble servant,

Marcellus

June 4th, 1878

Okay, so, anyway, the last job, I was not up there, but it was all very strange. I mean, they call it “crew recall”, I mean, I still don’t really know what exactly happened, but I know not everyone made it back in one piece, and the company has no record of it.
