Statement of Nick Utter on his feelings for Reid Jackson, transcribed from a statement given at Crown Scientific, December 31st, 2016.

NICK (STATEMENT):
[FAINTLY]
I’m not going to lie to you. I can’t even remember what he looks like. I don’t know if he’s beautiful like the sun or all ragged and ugly and barely there like a black hole. It doesn’t matter. I barely remember my own name or whether I was married or divorced, whether I had children…

What is he? What is Reid Jackson to me?

I remember him. Because I remember he was so kind. When I told him I wanted to go, he went to bat for me.

It’s big out there, it’s dark, and it swallows. There’s a lot of bad things you can do there. You get a lot of time to think.

“It can’t reach you now,” he told me. “You’re safe here.”

And I wanted him to be right.

…

You were saying?

NICK (STATEMENT):
[Bitter laugh] I was just saying to myself, Apogee and perigee. You know them? I was just saying to myself, isn't that funny? Good people. Good people do bad things to each other. And I’d always wondered about that. Ever the optimist. Candide. But, you know, it doesn’t really matter. None of it.

You can’t help people, can you? To be honest, I’m bad at math.

[Bitter laugh]

[Chuckle]

I hope he has a good life, Reid, I hope he takes care of himself, I hope lives to be a hundred and never loses anyone he loves. I hope his dog has puppies. I hope people tell him they love him every day, and I hope someone he loves is always there to remind him to say it back. I hope he eats cake. I hope he’s happy. I hope he can be.

And… I hope he doesn’t forget me.

I’d like to leave behind something other than my name on a list.

…

And, you know, I hope it’s not all just hurt and silence in the end.

Statement of the Henhouse, regarding Walter M. Henning on the day Marcellus passed away.

[HENHOUSE-TYPE HUMMING]
[THE STATEMENT IS WEARILY GIVEN]
My dearest, are you sure you want to hear this?

Well, when Marcellus passed away, it was a very long time since he'd been very well. It just kind of… rolled over him.

It happened in the night. There was a strange sort of peace to it, as though the whole world had quieted down for a moment. There was no drive or intent, no will behind it. He simply was and then he wasn’t.

This is all.

And then… Walter woke up alone.

And he was sad, and he was thirsty. So he went to the water pump, and he put his head under the pump. And he let the water pour over his hair and onto his face, and he let it fill his mouth and wash out all of his sadness.

And he stood there in the water, and he thought about the world and what it was and what it was like now that Marcellus was gone. And he thought about everything, and he thought about nothing, and he was still thirsty.

And he looked up and he saw the clouds, and he knew that they were made of water and that one day they were going to be rain again. He knew that the air was full of water and that the plants were made of water and that all the animals and all the people were made of water, too. He looked down and he saw his wet feet, and then he looked up at the clouds again, and he laughed.

This is all.

After that, we put Marcellus back into the ground. We did that, and we ached for a while. And after that, we talked and sang, and he was in the stories we told, and he was in the songs we sang. And we remembered how he looked and all the things he did, and we remembered his laughter, and we missed him because he was gone.

And we were sad.

And then we started our lives again without him.

This is all.

statement of Martin Blackwood regarding his date with Tim Stoker

MARTIN (STATEMENT): 
Well, this is, uh… Holy shit man oh my god. Tim Stoker. Right, I know, I know, I know. Tim Stoker. It’s a…

It’s a- I mean, it’s a name, isn’t it? Tim Stoker. Tim Stoker is a name. He’s just-

He’s just a guy, yeah. He’s just a fella. Tim Stoker. I mean sure I mean sure you’ve heard of him haven’t you? Of course you have. Who lives in the world, okay? A guy who lives in the world. I mean, he walks around and he goes, “Hey, Martin, what are you doing tonight?” and I say, “Um, I don’t know, haven’t thought about it,” but really, I’m thinking, “Oh, the box set of Firefly,” and this guy goes, “Okay, I’ll come round then,” and I’m like, “Cool,” but, actually it’s not cool because I wanted to watch Firefly, but you know? You can't say, “Tim, sorry, but the one thing I want to do this evening is sit in front of the TV and watch a box set of a TV show that was cancelled after 13 episodes,” so I said, “yes”.

And he’s like, “Thank you.” Wait. No, he doesn’t just say that. He does that, “Thank you.” Like some sort of subtly magical thing. I mean, I-I feel like I know him, but… but he doesn’t know me. And that’s like, like a, a very specific thing that, like…

Anyway he comes round, and he's like, “Oh, I could use a beer. Do you have any beer?” And I go, “No, I don't have any beer,” and he goes, “That’s okay,” and I go, “I have V8,” and he goes, “Oh, okay, do you have any vodka?” And I go, “No, I have V8.” And he’s like, “Ten-four, good buddy.” I go, “I don’t really drink.” and he goes, “That’s cool.” I go, “It’s really not.” So he says, “What do you want to do tonight?” and I said, “I don’t know, I didn’t have anything planned.” and he says, “Well, how about we go to the park and feed the ducks.” I say, “It’s too cold.” and he goes, “Okay, what do you want to do?” and I said, “I don’t know,” and he says, “What would you like to do?” and I said, “I really just want to sit in and watch some TV,” and he goes, “That sounds good. I’m just going to stare at you anyway,” and I go, “Okay,” and he leans over- and I kiss him you know how sometimes you lean over and you kiss somebody or they kiss you and it just feels right? It’s not like, “Oh shit, I need to make this quick because I’m baking a cake,” it’s not like that at all, it’s just… [nervous laugh]

hope, when did you know breekon was the one?

Avatar
HOPE: 
(small laugh, a bit too pronounced) They always were. We were built to be together, like this.

[Hope holds up two hands, palms open and pressed together.]

HOPE: 
But I do remember the first time I knew I loved him. He had been a strange and brilliant creature, but sometimes he seemed a tragedy. [gives a sly grin] He ate a chicken, just to see what it would do. Feathers stuck in his hair. He carried mortality around with him like a blessing. I loved him then because I wanted to wipe all the blood from his mouth and wash him clean.

It was different after that. That big, wild thing, he was mine first, and I too, wild and only his. The thrill was not the same as the fear, though. It was better.
